transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey, everyone.
Thank you for coming.
I'm Franco, co-founder and CEO at the Numbit Foundation.
And today, I'm going to be telling you a bit about the story
of how we got here, what we're working on,
and a bit of vision for the organization.
To Numbit Foundation, Ethereum dedicates a nonprofit.
We basically build developer infrastructure
and developer tooling to improve Ethereum developer experience.
That means we're working for Ethereum.
We're dedicated to Ethereum and trying
to empower developers to decentralize the world.
So we're best known for building hardhat.
Hardhat is the leading developer tool
Ethereum ecosystem beyond developers
used it to build tasks on the hardware software.
There's a whole ecosystem of community plugins
and nice things going on there.
But we didn't always do this.
And I'll share a bit of the story of how we got here.
We got involved with Ethereum in 2017.
We built contracts, dabs.
We audited stuff.
But by 2018, we started focusing on audits
and out of our own need to be more effective when
doing technical work.
We started working on our developer tool.
While all the same time, we were exploring what to do.
We were founders trying to find what we actually
wanted to work on and all these were just our way of paying
the bills.
But we needed to be more effective.
So we created a visitor, which then in 2020
became hardhat because that was an awful name.
And it was for internal use.
We open sourced it.
Some of our friends liked it.
People started using it.
So a need for it.
We applied for a grant from the Ethereum Foundation,
which they gave to us.
And we spent the rest of the year continuing our exploration
for what we wanted to do while working on this item on B
there to deliver on the problem of that.
We set up for the grant.
But by 2019, we realized that something needed to change.
We needed to focus on something to actually do it well.
And we have-- or actually my co-founder,
this year, had this vision for what hardhat could grow into.
I know there were big missing things.
And we knew that if we just built out these things
that we're missing, there was a lot of value
that we could add to all the people.
And we were just thinking about the level of productivity
that people were dealing with.
And if we managed to improve that very significantly,
it was very interesting to think what it could mean
for an entire Ethereum ecosystem.
So with four months of runway in the one,
we decided to drop all of the team
and focus on our little open source
project that had maybe 10, 15 users.
So yeah.
That's where our relationship with the Ethereum Foundation
started.
He focused-- my co-founder focused on building.
I went out to get some more money.
I asked absolutely everyone that was close to the EVM.
It was 2018, the year where the young killers were hot.
So I asked everyone for money.
Almost no one gave us money.
But we had a executive relationship with Ethereum
Foundation.
So we were doing a conversation on going there.
And through that, we ended up meeting some people
at the management team of Ethereum Foundation
who turned out were looking for ways for people
in the community that could help them improve
the Ethereum developer experience.
They knew it was an issue.
The new improvement.
And what they found in us was a team
that had a working product, some users,
a diagnosis of the situation, a concrete plan.
And we were looking for funding.
So it was a pretty good match.
We started collaborating with them.
They gave us another small grant to implement solidity
stack traces.
And as part of this same collaboration,
we would generally help them improve Ethereum.
This was not just working on hardhat,
but how do we make Ethereum as a whole better?
And when they are putting together a very small--
or relatively small--
roadmap of projects that we thought
were very high priority, high impact.
That could be delivered quickly and would
make a meaningful difference in short amount of time.
We worked on that.
It was great.
Went really well.
We hit it off.
And by 2020, the relationship took another step.
And we became what EF calls delegated domain allocators,
which is EF terminology for when they empower someone
in the community to allocate EF resources
to improve specific domain within Ethereum.
So basically, it's also funding us more aggressively
and allowing us to allocate more funding.
We started giving our grants.
We spent a bit less than the first quarter
of the year doing a lot of research
time to figure out where the sources of all of these issues.
And we worked on things.
We worked on many things.
But to give you an idea of the Ethereum general Ethereum
brushes that we worked on, we got GitHub to have solidity
syntax highlighting on by default before you needed to use
an obscure dot file in your repo for that to work.
We entirely replaced the cryptography dependencies
that were being used across the stack.
That was a pretty big project today
that's called Ethereum cryptography, where we put together

And that led to the entire thing being a lot more reliable

So this is some example of 17 different brushes

Just to give you an idea of it was just
pure Ethereum and not really anything related to Harhead.
So 2020, Harhead really takes off.
It was an anti-2021 that got really crazy.

The professional core ecosystem of Ethereum
had mostly all of them adopted Harhead.
And this was great.
All of the fun people were very happy with the product.
And we learned a ton.
By the end of the year, we realized a whole bunch of things.
These are, I think, the main takeaways.
The main one being doing this is very hard.
Building sophisticated tooling, it's
for Ethereum specifically in its current state.
It's super challenging.
And we realized that the next 10x--
so with all of this work and all the other things
I went on that year in the ecosystem,
Ethereum DevX improves hugely.
And there is still a lot more that can be done.
And we realized that the next 10x is not going to come from Harhead.

So just having a few or one or two solutions for each thing,
usually it's not the case in larger platforms.
So we know that what we need is not another specific feature.
It's not about missing functionality.
The next big step up is more about general growth
and more availability and diversity within the tool
within the ecosystem, which is the third point.
So we knew Uplan, Harhead and everything else

this needs to be better.
That's going to be better.
But then we needed an entirely new plan,

We're actually that many.
In one year, we call it most of it.
So for 2021 and forward, we came up with a new plan

The things that went there that we would have loved

and we decided not to.

and instead turned into a nonprofit--
our bunch, and I can't cover them all--
and some have to do with what we think
is best for Ethereum in the long term,
and many others have a lot to do with just personal things,

We had spent the past year and a half, basically

It was the right vehicle at the time to deliver value

And this was an amazing experience,
super gratifying, super challenging, simulating.

Another thing is that developer experience,
we think is absolutely core crucial and critical to Ethereum,
and it's also very hard.
Now, there's a lot of attention that
goes to the work being done on the protocol layer,
and makes sense.
It's amazing work, the merch has been an insane feat
of engineering.
And without taking any kind of credit away

we shouldn't forget that all of that work

The network supports the value proposition,

So if we have the most amazing scalable network

then that's a significant issue for Ethereum.
So we think this is a really valuable contribution
that we can make to the project.
And then the entire view of innovation in the ecosystem
and its growth are very much directly affected
by developer productivity.
The faster your developers can write code, iterate, debug,
test, launch, and repeat.
The faster everything will improve,
the more users will be captured, generally,
by improving developer experience,
we inject productivity into every single team
into the ecosystem, which has a super powerful compounding
effect over the long term, like faster, faster, faster,
faster, faster, faster.
And then the last one, tell me, you're
from a developer country without saying you're
from a developer country.
Crypto has no use cases.
As Arsen time founders got involved with crypto in 2015,

it was really obvious that this thing had the potential

and which is very big believers in what this can change

So how are we going to do all of this?
How are we actually going to empower developers

I mentioned before we came up with a new plan that

And for that, we're basically building new infrastructure

These two components, slang and ref nets,
are actually one same project, massive project,
with two very large components.
Slang is a new Solidity compiler that we're building,

the very core of it is the compiler

it can be a lot easier and more effective than it is today.
And this isn't meant to replace SolC.
SolC, it's compiled and you deploy it to main it.

It's going to be used during the development process.
Because its main target audience is tool developers.
And what we care about is basically
making sure that there are great insights during the development

And by not aiming for a main deployment,
we're actually able to read ourselves
a lot of very difficult constraints

So these two compilers are actually

There are one ref net.
It's going to be a reusable deviant runtime,

a pre-complex piece of software.
With completely different objectives and constraints,
it's basically an Ethereum node.

It's what we've all done.
Truffle, Brownie, Remix.
We've all built the same thing, which

When you use main and working in hard-hat,

hat very much remains a very core priority for NOMIC,
